Fact.Description: The taxpayers's jobs
The total income from a specific job
Pre-tax deductions from a specific job
The year-to-date withholding from a specific job
The average withholding from a specific job per pay period
Whether this job was held for the entire tax year.
Flow control: whether to ask start and end dates for this job.
The first date the job was held in the current calendar year, if not an all year job.
The last date the job was held in the current calendar year, if not an all year job.
The first date the job was held in the current calendar year.
The last date the job was held in the current calendar year.
The date which the most recent pay period ended on for this particular job
The date on which pay was received, corresponding to the most recent pay period that ended

Fact.Name: Pay Frequency Options
Fact.Description: Options for pay frequency

Fact.Name: Pay Frequency
Fact.Description: The frequency that the job pays the user. And the length of pay periods.
Length of pay periods matching the Floor of Publication 15-T values.
A preliminary calculation of remaining pay periods for weekly and biweekly frequencies, to be adjusted because it may extend past the end of the year.
For weekly and biweekly jobs, the final pay date predicted by the tentative calculation of remaining pay periods-- which may be past the end of year.
mostRecentPayPeriodEnd is on the last day of the month
Has lagging payments from the prior year
For semimonthly pay periods, determines the earlier pay period ending date
For semimonthly pay periods, determines the later pay period ending date

The number of pay dates remaining in the year.
Monthly and semimonthly are computed directly.
Weekly and biweekly are computed using `../tentativeRemainingPayPeriods` and `../predictedOrdinalFinalPayDate` to make any necessary adjustment when the tentative calculation overflows the end of year. For example, let's say you are paid weekly every Friday for the previous week, and you're working through EOY. Then (in 2025) you will be paid on the 2nd of January 2026 for 12/21-27, and on the 9th of January 2026 for 12/28-01/03. That's two pay periods that are in 2025 that will be paid for (and taxed in) 2026.
The month in which the user last worked as far as income counting towards this year is concerned, used for semi-monthly and monthly
The date that is effectively the user's last day worked for this job as far as income counting towards this year is concerned
similar to jobs/*/effectiveEndDate but only up to the last full pay period
Similar to jobs/*/ordinalEffectiveEndDate but only until the end of the last full payment
Is paid for a partial partial period
# of full pay periods that are left to be paid this year
Rationale representing the fractional pay period that is paid
The total amount of bonus per year for a specific job
Threshold for changing bonus withholdings from 22% to 37%
Bonus withholdings are 22% if less than 1,000,000 and 37% on the sum exceeding 1,000,000
Form W-4 Line 4(a); also Pub 15-T Worksheet 1A Line 1d.
Form W-4 Line 4(b); also Pub 15-T Worksheet 1A Line 1f.
This is derived from the "2197 Scenarios checks" worksheet of the "TWESprint1_2025_UAT_WHC2197_2200" spreadsheet.
Line 1g of Pub 15-T Worksheet 1A
Line 1i of Pub 15-T Worksheet 1A

Standard withholding rate schedules for use when Form W-4 Step 2 box is not checked. Line 2g of Pub. 15-T Worksheet 1A. These amounts are generally a base withholding amount plus a percentage of the excess of Annual Adjusted Wages Amount. The base withholding captures the total withholding for all the brackets below the one that the AAWA falls into.
Line 2h of Pub. 15-T Worksheet 1A. The amount from the Annual Method Percentage table.
The end of year amount withheld for this job if nothing is changed.
This amount this job will pay for the rest of the year.
This job's withholding that cannot change because it's past or within the time lag before W4 changes kick in.
Total income from jobs + any W-4 Line 4a incomes (non-job, non-pension/annuity).
The sum of all other taxable pension income, excluding the income from the single highest paying pension.
Sum of Line 2bi and 2bii, may be negative.
Total non-job or pension/annuity income.
Other deductions to income.
Projected yearly pay with deductions removed.
Adjusted total other income (2c), or adjusted annual payment amount (2d).

Standard withholding rate schedules for the form W-4P. Line 2j of Pub. 15-T Worksheet 1B. These amounts are generally a base withholding amount plus a percentage of the excess of Annual Adjusted Wages Amount. The base withholding captures the total withholding for all the brackets below the one that the AAWA falls into.

Standard withholding rate schedules for use when Form W-4P Step 2(b)iii box is filled. Line 2s of Pub. 15-T Worksheet 1b. These amounts are generally a base withholding amount plus a percentage of the excess of Annual Adjusted Wages Amount. The base withholding captures the total withholding for all the brackets below the one that the AAWA falls into.
The tentative annual withholding amount. Pub. 15T Worksheet 1B Line 2u.
Line 4c of Pub. 15-T Worksheet 1B. The per-period withholding amount sub credits, excluding any extra elected on Form W-4P Line 4(c).
Jobs that are ended or end too soon are not candidates for extra withholding on a new W4.
The job selected for extra withholding on a new W4. The W4 refers to this as the "highest paying job".
Total income for all jobs
Total actual withholding for all jobs
The amount withheld for all jobs if nothing is changed.
The rest-of-year withholding gap: taxes owed if nothing is changed.
The start date of the pension this year
The end date of the pension this year
Average withholding from a specific pension per pay-period.
Length of pay periods matching the Floor of Publication 15-T values.
This is derived from the "2197 Scenarios checks" worksheet of the "TWESprint1_2025_UAT_WHC2197_2200" spreadsheet.
The number of pay dates remaining for this pension that will be paid out within the calendar year.
Total income from all pensions.
Net self-employment income as reported on line 3 of Schedule SE (Form 1040).
Specific calculation on line 6 of Schedule SE (Form 1040) to multiply net self employment income by 92.35%.
Taxable self-employment income from lines 4-5 on Schedule SE (Form 1040).
Self-employment tax multiplied by the Social Security tax rate from line 10 on Schedule SE (Form 1040).
Self-employment tax multiplied by the Medicare tax rate from line 11 on Schedule SE (Form 1040).
Self-employment tax instructions from line 12 on Schedule SE (Form 1040).
Ordinary dividends income
Unemployment insurance income
Interest income excluding non-taxable interest
Short term capital gains income
Long term capital gains income
Amount of qualified dividends estimated by tax payer.
Taxable income from scholarships
Alimony received income
S-corp non-passive income (Schedule K1)
Net Schedule E income
Non-specific other income
SSA Income from forms SSA-1099 and RRB-1099
Non-taxable interest income. Used to calculate modified AGI for calculating taxable amount of SSA benefits
If TP has MFS filing status and lived with their spouse at any time during the TY
Sum of adjustments from Form 1044 Schedule 1. Student loan interest deduction should not be included. IRS Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 7.
Modifed AGI used to determine taxable amount of SSA benefits. IRS Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 8.

Threshold when taxable portion of SSA Benefits changes from 0% to 50%. Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 9. If SSA MAGI (Line 8) is less than $32K for MFJ and $25K for anybody else, 0% of SSA benefits are taxed. This is our bracket zero. Taxable portion of SSA MAGI which is more than bracket zero but less than $32K + $12K for MFJ and $25K + $9K for evereryone else, is 50%, not to exceed 50% of SSA Benefits total. Taxable portion of SSA MAGI which is more than $32K + $12K for MFJ and $25K + $9K for evereryone else, is 85%, not to exceed 85% of SSA Benefits total. If TP is MFS which lived together for any part of the year, all SSA Benefits are taxed at 85%.
MAGI which exceeds zero threshold. Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 10
Income bracket where taxable portion is 50%. Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 11
Amount of MAGI with taxable portion 50%. Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 13
Taxable amount for 50% bracket. Should not exceed 50% of total SSA Benefits. Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 15
Taxable amount for 85% bracket. Pub 915 Worksheet 1, Line 16
Taxable amount of Social Security benefits to enter in Form 1040 line 6b. Ranges from 0% to up to 50% to up to 85% of total SSA benefits

Fact.Name: OB3 70204: Distribution from Trump Account as defined by IRC 530A
Fact.Description: The term "Trump account" means an individual retirement account (as defined in section 408(a)) which is not designated as a Roth IRA and which meets certain investment requirements
Other sources of income. Taxable portion of SSA benefits not included. Used to calculate taxable portion onf SSA benefits

§ 931 - Income from sources within Guam, American Samoa, or the Northern Mariana Islands
§ 933. Income from sources within Puerto Rico
Qualified Tip Income
Fact.Description: OB3 §70201; IRC §224. Qualified tip income

Fact.Name: Overtime Compensation Excluding Qualified Tip Overtime Comp
Fact.Description: OB3 §70202 IRC §225(c)(2). Overtime compensation excluding all qualified tips defined in IRC §224 that were received as part of qualified overtime compensation
